extendedIngredients.name: baking potatoes
extendedIngredients.original: 1 pound baking potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice
extendedIngredients.originalName: baking potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice

extendedIngredients.name: corn kernels
extendedIngredients.original: 1 10-ounce package frozen corn kernels, thawed (2 cups)

extendedIngredients.name: trout fillets
extendedIngredients.original: 1 pound smoked trout fillets, skinned and torn into large flakes

title: Smoked Trout Hash with Potatoes and Corn
summary: Smoked Trout Hash with Potatoes and Corn might be just the side dish you are searching for. This gluten free, dairy free, and pescatarian recipe serves 4 and costs $3.31 per serving. One serving contains 419 calories, 34g of protein, and 16g of fat. 1 person has made this recipe and would make it again. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes around 35 minutes. Head to the store and pick up trout fillets, salt and pepper, scallions, and a few other things to make it today. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 70%. This score is solid. Try Smoked Trout Hash, Lemony Smoked Trout Hash, and Smoked Trout Hash With Mustard Greens for similar recipes.
instructions: Heat the oil in a large cast-iron skillet. Add the potatoes and cook over moderate heat, tossing, until tender and golden brown, 5 to 6 minutes. Add the scallions and onion and cook until softened. Add the corn and trout and cook, stirring, until heated through. Season the hash with salt and pepper.                                              In a shallow pan of simmering water, poach the eggs until the whites are set and the yolks are still runny, about 3 minutes. Remove the eggs with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Mound the hash on plates, top with the eggs and serve at once.

steps.step: Heat the oil in a large cast-iron skillet.
Add the potatoes and cook over moderate heat, tossing, until tender and golden brown, 5 to 6 minutes.
Add the scallions and onion and cook until softened.
Add the corn and trout and cook, stirring, until heated through. Season the hash with salt and pepper.
In a shallow pan of simmering water, poach the eggs until the whites are set and the yolks are still runny, about 3 minutes.
Remove the eggs with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Mound the hash on plates, top with the eggs and serve at once.
